history.content:
Not an expert but I think most people usually have one of their letters from a manager/team lead in industry. I think a letter from your proposed advisor is basically a must, so definitely prioritize getting that, and the third letter is probably okay if it's a bit weaker. (Again, not an expert!!) 

For TAing, you'll need permission from your advisor (they need to sign a form). Also 5th year MS students cost more to hire for whatever reason, which may or may not be a problem depending on the budget for the class you want to teach.

children.subject: I did one from my research professor, one from the grad student I was working with, and one from the professor I TA for. And if you don't have prior experience TAing, my guess would be that it would be hard to get a TA job. What I've seen in 61a is they give the MS students a 10 hour TA job and they usually don't teach, they do Head TA jobs (so backend stuff you usually need experience with the class to know). Just a guess though. As for out of state, I'm in a bit of a fight with the registrar about this. I'm guessing you will have lived here for four years like I have and logically that should be enough in my opinion (I've been paying taxes to the state of CA for two years), but this is the website you need to know (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/tuition-fees-residency/residency-tuition-purposes/in-state-tuition-graduate-students). It's highly deceitful though. If you are out of state and already effectively living in CA, what does it mean to "move" to the state? Not particularly clear. If you read the 30 page PDF linked, not particularly clear. May cost me $7k. Don't make my mistake, if you read the PDF it says you need to get a driver's license and register to vote 1 year prior to the 5th Yr Master's program. So do it by this fall if possible. Feel free to email me at rmoughan@berkeley.edu if you get in and need to know more about the out of state issues.

history.content:
I heard we need 3 letters of recommendation. I'm interning at Google this summer, so would my manager/team lead be a valid letter of rec? I'm hoping to find a faculty member to research with, so that's another letter of rec. Would a third letter of rec, from a professor who I didn't really interact with, but did well in the class, be a good idea? I expect to have ~3.9 GPA when I graduate.

Also, given that master's students don't get any funding, how difficult would it be to get a TA job (I'm out of state, so predictably, money is an issue). I was thinking about TAing so that I don't need to pay the in-state tuition part.
history.subject: 5th year masters
